newsitem.title: UK: EU seen awarding up to 100,000 T sugar at tender.
newsitem.headline: EU seen awarding up to 100,000 T sugar at tender.

text.p: The European Union (EU) is expected to award up to 100,000 tonnes of current series white sugar at its weekly tender on Wednesday, the ninth of the new series for the 1996/97 crop, traders said.
One trader forecast this week's authorised tonnage at between 80,000 and 90,000 tonnes, after the EU awarded 79,500 in its last tender on September 25.
But another, noting a large amount of hedge sales during Tuesday's session, forecast a wider range between 60,000 and 100,000 tonnes.
"I think people are thinking it's time to get rid of it (EU sugar) before the market gets any worse and I think they also want to make room for the C sugar sales," he said.
"If the market is soft, they'd rather it was soft now than when they want to start selling."
Traders broadly agreed on the maximum restitution for licences this week and forecast between 45.060 and 45.064 Ecus (European Currency Units) per 100 kg of sugar, after last week's 44.709 Ecus.
Export licences are currently valid from October to March. --Jeremy Smith, London Newsroom +44 171 542 8064
